collections.title: Top 100 Verbs

words.definition: To exist; to have a specific quality or identity
examples: I am happy.
She is a teacher.
I have a car.
She has three children.

words.definition: To perform or carry out an action
examples: What do you do for work?
I do my homework every day.
What did you say?
She says hello to everyone.
I need to get some milk.
She got a promotion at work.
I make coffee every morning.
She makes beautiful paintings.

words.definition: To move from one place to another
examples: I go to work by bus.
Let's go to the movies.

words.definition: To have information or understanding about something
examples: I know the answer.
Do you know where she lives?

words.definition: To get hold of something and move it
examples: Take your umbrella with you.
I'll take the bus to work.
I can see the mountains.
Did you see that movie?

words.definition: To move toward or arrive at a place
examples: Come here please.
She comes to visit every week.

words.definition: To have a particular opinion or belief
examples: I think it's a good idea.
What do you think about this?

words.definition: To direct one's gaze toward someone or something
examples: Look at that beautiful sunset.
She looks tired today.

words.definition: To have a desire to possess or do something
examples: I want a cup of coffee.
What do you want for dinner?

words.definition: To transfer the possession of something to someone
examples: Give me your hand.
She gives great advice.
I use my phone every day.
How do you use this machine?
I can't find my keys.
She found a new job.
Tell me about your day.
He told a funny story.
Ask me any question.
She asked for directions.

words.definition: To be engaged in physical or mental activity
examples: I work at a bank.
This plan won't work.

words.definition: To give the impression of being something
examples: It seems like a good idea.
She seems happy today.

words.definition: To experience an emotion or sensation
examples: I feel tired today.
How do you feel about this?
Try to be on time.
I'll try my best.

words.definition: To go away from a place
examples: I leave work at 5 PM.
Don't leave me alone.
Call me later.
I'll call you tomorrow.

words.definition: To be obliged to do something
examples: You must study hard.
I must go now.
I will help you.
She will come tomorrow.
Use your time wisely.
Can I use your phone?
Find a good restaurant.
I found my lost keys.

words.definition: To transfer the possession of something
examples: Give me a chance.
She gave me a gift.
Tell me the truth.
He told a joke.
The machine works well.
This strategy works.
What do you call this?
They call him John.
Try this food.
I tried the new restaurant.

words.definition: To invite someone to do something
examples: Ask him to come.
She asked me to help.
I need some help.
We need more time.
Feel this fabric.
I can feel the wind.
She became a doctor.
It's becoming dark.

words.definition: To place something in a position
examples: Put the book on the table.
I put my keys in my pocket.

words.definition: To intend to convey or refer to
examples: What do you mean?
I mean what I say.

words.definition: To continue to have or hold
examples: Keep your money safe.
I keep my promises.

words.definition: To allow someone to do something
examples: Let me help you.
Don't let him go.
Let's begin the meeting.
I begin work at 9 AM.

words.definition: To make it easier for someone to do something
examples: Can you help me?
I help my mother cook.

words.definition: To move in a circular direction
examples: Turn left at the corner.
The wheel turns slowly.
Start the engine.
I start school tomorrow.

words.definition: To take or carry something with you
examples: Bring your umbrella.
She brings lunch to work.

words.definition: To compose or set down on paper
examples: Write your name here.
I write in my diary daily.
The school provides books.
I provide help when needed.
Sit down please.
I sit at my desk all day.

words.definition: To be in an upright position
examples: Stand up straight.
I stand in line at the store.
Don't lose your keys.
I lose weight by exercising.

words.definition: To give money for goods or services
examples: I pay the bill.
She pays for her education.

words.definition: To come into the presence of someone
examples: Nice to meet you.
We meet every Tuesday.

words.definition: To comprise or contain as part of a whole
examples: The price includes tax.
Please include your contact information.

words.definition: To keep doing something without stopping
examples: Continue with your work.
The rain continues all day.

words.definition: To put something in a particular place
examples: Set the table for dinner.
I set my alarm for 7 AM.
I learn English every day.
Children learn quickly.
Change your clothes.
The weather changes often.
Lead the way.
She leads the team.

words.definition: To perceive the meaning of something
examples: I understand the problem.
Do you understand me?

words.definition: To look at or observe attentively
examples: Watch the movie with me.
I watch TV every evening.

words.definition: To go or come after someone
examples: Follow me to the office.
The dog follows its owner.

words.definition: To cease moving or doing something
examples: Stop the car here.
I stop working at 5 PM.
Create a new document.
Artists create beautiful paintings.

words.definition: To say words in order to communicate
examples: Speak clearly please.
I speak three languages.

words.definition: To look at and comprehend written text
examples: Read this book.
I read the newspaper daily.
Allow me to help you.
The teacher allows questions.
Add sugar to the coffee.
I add new words to my vocabulary.

words.definition: To use money to pay for something
examples: I spend money on books.
She spends time with family.

words.definition: To increase in size or develop
examples: Plants grow in the garden.
Children grow quickly.

words.definition: To move something to allow access
examples: Open the door please.
I open my eyes in the morning.

words.definition: To move on foot at a regular pace
examples: Walk to the store.
I walk my dog every day.

words.definition: To be successful in a contest
examples: We win the game.
She wins the competition.
I offer you my help.
The store offers discounts.

words.definition: To have in or be able to bring to one's mind
examples: Remember to call me.
I remember my childhood.

words.definition: To feel deep affection for someone
examples: I love my family.
She loves reading books.
Consider all options.
I consider him a friend.
The sun appears in the morning.
She appears happy today.

words.definition: To obtain something by paying for it
examples: I buy groceries every week.
She buys a new car.

words.definition: To stay in one place until something happens
examples: Wait for me here.
I wait for the bus.

words.definition: To perform duties or services for someone
examples: Serve the customers well.
I serve my country.
The flowers die without water.
He died peacefully.

words.definition: To cause something to go to another place
examples: Send me an email.
I send a letter to my friend.

words.definition: To regard something as likely to happen
examples: I expect good results.
She expects to arrive on time.

words.definition: To construct something by putting parts together
examples: Build a house.
I build my career step by step.

words.definition: To remain in the same place
examples: Stay here with me.
I stay at home today.

words.definition: To move downward under the force of gravity
examples: The leaves fall in autumn.
Don't fall down the stairs.

words.definition: To make an opening or incision with a sharp tool
examples: Cut the paper with scissors.
I cut my finger accidentally.

words.definition: To stretch out an arm to touch something
examples: Reach for the stars.
I can't reach the top shelf.

words.definition: To cause the death of a living thing
examples: The poison kills insects.
Time kills all pain.

words.definition: To continue to exist or be left over
examples: Only a few questions remain.
I remain optimistic.
I suggest we go home.
She suggests a new approach.

words.definition: To lift or move to a higher position
examples: Raise your hand if you know the answer.
They raise their children well.

words.definition: To move past or through something
examples: Pass me the salt please.
I pass the test easily.

words.definition: To give something in exchange for money
examples: I sell my old car.
The store sells books.

words.definition: To need something for a particular purpose
examples: This job requires experience.
The law requires a license.

words.definition: To give an account of something
examples: Report the accident to the police.
I report to my boss daily.

words.definition: To make a choice or reach a conclusion
examples: Decide what you want to eat.
I decide to study harder.

words.definition: To exert force on something to move it toward oneself
examples: Pull the door to open it.
I pull the rope hard.

collections.description: The 100 most common verbs in English

collections.title: Gen Z Slang

words.definition: Delusional, often used for unrealistic optimism in romance
examples: She's being delulu about that celebrity crush.
Stop being delulu, he's not into you.

words.definition: Absurd or chaotic, from viral memes
examples: This situation is so skibidi right now.
The party was completely skibidi.
He's got serious rizz with the ladies.
Your rizz game is strong tonight.
She has such a positive aura.
Your aura is glowing today.

words.definition: Male-dominated power structures in casual settings
examples: The broligarchy at this gym is real.
We need to break down this broligarchy.

words.definition: Short for inspiration, like mood board ideas
examples: I need some fashion inspo for the party.
This Pinterest board is full of inspo.

words.definition: Major transformation in appearance or confidence
examples: Her glow-up since high school is incredible.
Time for my glow-up era.
You absolutely slayed that presentation.
She's slaying in that outfit.
I'm getting good vibes from this place.
The vibes at this party are immaculate.
This concert is absolutely lit.
That was a lit performance.
He's always flexing his new car.
Stop flexing your grades.
I'm getting hangry, let's eat soon.
Don't talk to me when I'm hangry.

words.definition: Fear of being without your phone
examples: I have serious nomophobia when my phone dies.
Her nomophobia is getting out of control.

collections.description: Trending slang from social media and youth culture

collections.title: AI and Tech Buzzwords

words.definition: Generative artificial intelligence, like chatbots creating content
examples: Gen AI is revolutionizing content creation.
The company invested heavily in Gen AI technology.

words.definition: Skill in using AI tools effectively
examples: AI fluency is becoming essential in modern workplaces.
She developed strong AI fluency through practice.

words.definition: Virtual reality worlds for social and work interactions
examples: Companies are building offices in the metaverse.
The metaverse promises new ways to connect.
She became a digital nomad and works from Bali.
Digital nomads are changing the future of work.

words.definition: Doing the minimum at work without overcommitting
examples: Quiet quitting is a response to burnout culture.
Many employees are practicing quiet quitting.
His waifu is from a popular anime series.
Virtual waifus are popular in gaming culture.
We're entering a new tech supercycle.
The AI supercycle is transforming industries.
He sold his NFT for thousands of dollars.
NFTs represent ownership of digital art.

words.definition: Digital clothing for avatars in games or metaverses
examples: Virtual fashion is a growing industry.
She designs virtual fashion for gaming avatars.

words.definition: Set of rules for AI decision-making
examples: The algorithm determines what content you see.
Machine learning algorithms improve over time.
Blockchain technology ensures data security.
Cryptocurrency relies on blockchain networks.
Write a clear prompt for better AI results.
The prompt engineering course was very helpful.

collections.description: Rising with Gen AI advancements and digital nomad lifestyles

examples: Eco-minimalism helps reduce environmental impact.

As a climavore, she avoids beef and dairy.
Climavores choose foods with low carbon footprints.
Flying increases your carbon footprint significantly.
We're working to reduce our company's carbon footprint.

words.definition: Reuse waste creatively into something valuable
examples: She upcycles old jars into beautiful planters.
Upcycling reduces waste and saves money.
The zero-waste movement is growing rapidly.
She follows a zero-waste lifestyle with reusable containers.
Sustainable fashion uses eco-friendly materials.
We need sustainable solutions for climate change.
Protecting biodiversity is crucial for our planet.
The rainforest has incredible biodiversity.

words.definition: Energy sources like solar that replenish naturally
examples: Solar and wind are renewable energy sources.
The country aims for 100% renewable electricity.
We compost our food scraps in the backyard.
Composting reduces landfill waste significantly.
Consumers are getting better at spotting greenwashing.
The company was accused of greenwashing their products.
Biodegradable packaging is better for the environment.
These bags are made from biodegradable materials.

That haircut is so trendy right now.

collections.title: Everyday Modern Phrases

examples: Don't pessimize about the exam results.

words.definition: Fictional dictionary entry to catch plagiarism
examples: The dictionary included a mountweazel to detect copying.

The complex instructions confuddled everyone.

I beseech you to reconsider your decision.

His abnegation of luxury impressed everyone.
Abnegation is often seen as a virtue in some cultures.

words.definition: Spoiled or cheeky person (trending from pop culture)
examples: She's such a brat when she doesn't get her way.

words.definition: Effortless charm (Korean trend influencing global slang)
examples: He has that egen-nam quality that everyone loves.

words.definition: Versatile slang for turn/bend/break (viral from entertainment)

Intrusive thoughts can be difficult to control.
She struggled with intrusive memories from the past.
The concept of purity is being questioned online.
Purity culture is a topic of debate in modern society.

examples: The cat is sleeping.

The weather was nice.
This gift is for you.

The door to my room is open.

collections.title: Abstract Concepts

examples: Deforestation is destroying wildlife habitats.

Environmental sustainability requires immediate action.
The company focuses on economic sustainability.
Rapid urbanization is changing rural landscapes.
Urbanization brings both opportunities and challenges.
New policies aim to alleviate poverty.
Technology can help alleviate traffic congestion.
The pandemic was a catalyst for digital transformation.
Education serves as a catalyst for social mobility.
Plastic waste is detrimental to marine life.
Lack of sleep is detrimental to academic performance.
The proliferation of social media has changed communication.
Nuclear proliferation remains a global concern.

collections.description: C2-level topic words for IELTS Task 2 essays on global issues

collections.title: Emotions and Relationships

examples: She showed great affection for her grandchildren.
The couple's affection for each other was evident.
His sudden departure left everyone in bewilderment.
The complex instructions caused bewilderment among students.
She found contentment in her simple lifestyle.
The peaceful garden brought him great contentment.
The failed exam filled him with despair.
In moments of despair, she turned to her family.
Good teachers show empathy toward struggling students.
Her empathy helped her connect with patients.
Winning the championship brought euphoria to the team.
The success of the project created a sense of euphoria.
There was clear hostility between the two groups.
The hostile environment made collaboration difficult.
The old photos filled her with nostalgia.
He felt nostalgia for his childhood summers.
Years of unfair treatment built up resentment.
She tried to let go of her resentment toward her former boss.
The mountain lake offered perfect serenity.
Meditation helped her find inner serenity.
Sharing his story showed great vulnerability.
The experience taught her about her own vulnerability.
She approached her work with remarkable zeal.
His zeal for learning inspired his classmates.

collections.description: Advanced C1 descriptors for TOEFL integrated tasks and personal narratives

collections.title: Idioms and Phrasal Verbs

examples: I told a joke to break the ice at the meeting.
She asked about the weather to break the ice with her new neighbor.
We've been working for hours - let's call it a day.
The team decided to call it a day after the successful presentation.
Don't cut corners when building the foundation.
The company cut corners to save money, but quality suffered.
I drew a blank when asked about the client's name.
She drew a blank during the exam despite studying hard.
He got cold feet before the wedding and almost didn't show up.
Don't get cold feet now - you've prepared well for this interview.

words.text: hit the nail on the head
examples: You hit the nail on the head with that analysis.
The teacher hit the nail on the head when explaining the problem.
Many companies are jumping on the bandwagon of remote work.
Don't just jump on the bandwagon - think for yourself.
Please keep an eye on the children while I'm cooking.
The manager asked me to keep an eye on the new employee.

words.text: let the cat out of the bag
words.phonetics: /let ðə kæt aʊt ʌv ðə bæɡ/
examples: I accidentally let the cat out of the bag about the surprise party.
The journalist let the cat out of the bag about the scandal.
The math test was a piece of cake for her.
Don't worry about the presentation - it'll be a piece of cake.
I'm just pulling your leg - of course I believe you.
Stop pulling my leg and tell me the real story.
Someone spilled the beans about the merger before the announcement.
I can't spill the beans about the surprise - it's a secret.
I'm feeling a bit under the weather today.
She called in sick because she was under the weather.

collections.description: C1-C2 expressions for natural fluency in IELTS speaking

collections.title: Top 30 Phrasal Verbs

examples: When the class was making fun of me, only the teacher backed me up.
I'll always back you up in this decision.
The ice cream machine at McDonald's often breaks down.
My car broke down on the highway yesterday.
Roy called around to find a nearby mechanic.
I'll call around to see who's available for the meeting.
We called the party off.
The game was called off due to rain.

words.definition: To relax after being energetic or irritated
examples: I need a few minutes to calm down after that match.
Please calm down and tell me what happened.
I'll check the contract out.
You should check out this new restaurant.

words.definition: To make someone happy when sad
examples: Reading always cheers me up on a rainy day.
Let's cheer her up with some ice cream.
Our hockey team cleaned up at the tournament.
The company cleaned up in the fourth quarter.
Her boss said she had to clean up or find a new job.
The politician promised to clean up his act.
I never liked seafood but came around after trying fried calamari.
She'll come around to the idea eventually.
After 50 years, nothing could come between them.
Don't let money come between you and your family.
After traveling, Chandra came down with a cold.
Half the office came down with the flu.
Some good came out of our boring class trip.
Nothing positive came out of that meeting.
The run time never came up in the conversation.
This topic always comes up at family dinners.
Sahar comes up with her best ideas at night.
We need to come up with a solution quickly.
I can count on my friends to warn me.
You can count on me to be there on time.
Police have been cracking down on drunk driving.
The school is cracking down on tardiness.
I'll dive into that new TV show tonight.
She dove into her new job with enthusiasm.
Abed dressed up for the award ceremony.
We're dressing up for the fancy dinner.
He ended up taking the job.
We ended up staying home instead of going out.
My new dress fell apart after two washes.
The old book fell apart when I opened it.
Bruce filled his water bottle up to the brim.
Please fill up the gas tank before returning the car.
We didn't find out the news until after dinner.
I need to find out what time the meeting starts.
They didn't get anything across to the students.
I couldn't get my point across in the meeting.
You'll never get ahead unless you follow the rules.
Hard work is the key to getting ahead in life.
My dog gets along with everyone but cats.
I get along with my new roommate very well.
It's impossible to get around without a car.
Public transportation helps people get around the city.
I'll get around to that after the playoffs.
I never got around to reading that book.
I can't get at this itch on my back.
The files are locked and I can't get at them.
Lucio goes to the lake to get away.
We need to get away from the city for a while.

collections.description: Essential for daily conversation and writing, ranked by commonality

collections.title: Top 15 Common Idioms

words.definition: A good thing that seemed bad at first
examples: Losing that job was a blessing in disguise, as it led to a better career.
The rain was a blessing in disguise for the farmers.
Those souvenirs are a dime a dozen at the tourist shop.
Good programmers are a dime a dozen in this city.

words.definition: Avoid saying what you mean, usually because it's uncomfortable
examples: Stop beating around the bush and tell me what you really think.
Don't beat around the bush - just tell me the truth.

words.definition: Better to arrive late than not at all
examples: I know I'm late, but better late than never, right?
She finally apologized - better late than never.

words.definition: To get something over with because it's inevitable
examples: I decided to bite the bullet and finish the difficult project.
It's time to bite the bullet and have that difficult conversation.
Break a leg in your performance tonight!
Break a leg on your job interview tomorrow.
We've been at this for hours; let's call it a day.
The team decided to call it a day after the successful presentation.
Cut him some slack; he's new and still learning.
Cut me some slack - I'm doing my best.

words.definition: Doing something poorly to save time or money
examples: By cutting corners, they finished quickly but with mistakes.
Don't cut corners when it comes to safety.
Easy does it when you're carrying that fragile vase.
Easy does it - we have plenty of time.
The party got out of hand and the neighbors called the police.
The situation is getting out of hand quickly.
If you don't get your act together, you might lose your job.
You need to get your act together and start taking this seriously.

words.text: give someone the benefit of the doubt
words.phonetics: /ɡɪv ˈsʌmwʌn ðə ˈbenəfɪt ʌv ðə daʊt/
examples: I'll give her the benefit of the doubt and believe she didn't mean to offend me.
Let's give him the benefit of the doubt this time.

words.text: go back to the drawing board
examples: Our plan failed, so it's time to go back to the drawing board.
The design didn't work, so we went back to the drawing board.
Hang in there; things will get better soon.
Hang in there - you're almost finished.

collections.description: Figurative expressions for natural fluency in speaking and reading
